title: Uromastyx Temperature and Humidity Control Guide
description: Temperature gradients, basking targets, and low-humidity management for Uromastyx.
excerpt: Temperature gradients, basking targets, and low-humidity management for Uromastyx.
author: Habitat Builder

content.text: Uromastyx are full-sun desert lizards. They need extreme basking heat, a strong thermal gradient, and low ambient humidity to digest food and stay healthy.

rows: Use a raised platform 10-12 in below heat lamp

content.content: Basking temperatures below 120 deg F often lead to poor digestion, low appetite, and chronic health issues.
Halogen flood bulbs are the best primary heat source for Uromastyx. Use a dimmer or thermostat to fine-tune surface temperatures.

rows: Night heat if room is cold

content.content: Best setup: Two halogen floods over a raised platform, controlled by a dimmer to reach 120-130 deg F surface temperatures.
Use a dimming thermostat or a dimmer with frequent temperature checks. Place probes where the lizard actually basks.

items: Place the primary probe on the basking surface, not hanging in the air.
Use a second probe on the cool side to verify the gradient.
Check surface temps with an infrared temperature gun daily during setup.

content.content: Unregulated heat can quickly exceed safe limits. Always control heat lamps with a dimmer or thermostat.
Keep ambient humidity low while providing a localized humid burrow. Avoid routine misting that raises overall humidity.

rows: Use vents or partial mesh top
Use rarely, only for burrow maintenance

content.content: Sustained humidity above 40% can lead to respiratory issues. Keep the surface substrate dry.
A modest seasonal light cycle change is enough for most keepers. Do not reduce basking temps below target ranges.

rows: Lamp too weak or platform too low
Enclosure too small or poor airflow
Water dish too large or poor airflow
Allow safe nighttime drop to 70-75 deg F
Basking temps or UVB too low
